title: Resource Annotator
page_title: Pacific Northwest History and Cultures: Coastal Region
introduction: Identity are the qualities and beliefs of an individual. Culture are shared beliefs, traditions, and practices of a group. A sense of community is a feeling of wanting to be with other people or of caring about the other people in a group.

themes.title: Identity
themes.tooltip_text: The qualities and beliefs of an individual

themes.title: Culture
themes.tooltip_text: Shared beliefs, traditions, and practices of a group

themes.title: A sense of community
themes.tooltip_text: A feeling of wanting to be with other people or of caring about the other people in a group

sources.title: Makah Days
sources.image_credit:
Image 1: Salmon grilling over a fire pit, 27th August, 2005. Neah Bay, Makah Indian Reservation, Washington, USA. Photo courtesy of Konrad Wothe/ imageBROKER/Alamy Stock Photo

Image 2: Makah Feast Day, Salmon Bake, ca. 1955. Photograph credited to Makah Tribe, http://exotichikes.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/makahfeastday_salmon-bake-c1955.jpg
sources.body:
Image 1: Salmon roasting at Makah Days, a period of celebration during which Makah citizens gather to honor thousands of years of customs and traditions as well as the anniversary of becoming United States citizens in 1924 under the American Indian Citizenship Act.

Image 2: Makah Days in the mid-1950s. Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest use cedar skewers to pierce, roast, and smoke salmon filets over open pit fires.
sources.caption:
Image 1: Salmon roasting at Makah Days, a period of celebration during which Makah citizens gather to honor thousands of years of customs and traditions as well as the anniversary of becoming United States citizens in 1924 under the American Indian Citizenship Act.

Image 2: Makah Days in the mid-1950s. Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest use cedar skewers to pierce, roast, and smoke salmon filets over open pit fires.
sources.excerpt:
Salmon roasting at Makah Days, a period of celebration during which Makah citizens gather to honor thousands of years of customs and traditions as well as the anniversary of becoming United States citizens in 1924 under the American Indian Citizenship Act.

Makah Days in the mid-1950s. Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest use cedar skewers to pierce, roast, and smoke salmon filets over open pit fires.
sources.question_text: What is the importance to individuals and communities in maintaining traditional salmon cooking methods?

sources.title: Fishing
sources.image_credit:
Image 1: Quileute iron salmon hook, ca.1890. NMAI 057591

Image 2: Quileute drift net for catching salmon, collected in 1916. Washington. NMAI 057870
sources.body:
Image 1: Native peoples engineered a variety of tools and techniques to harvest salmon. The hook-and-line method reflects the sustainable practice of taking enough fish for a family or community while leaving healthy, sustainable amounts of fish to spawn and migrate.

Image 2: A typical problem with certain kinds of modern nets is that they can be far too large and catch many non-commercial fish. This small Quileute set net, however, was made to target specific types and sizes of fish.
sources.excerpt:
Image 1: Native peoples engineered a variety of tools and techniques to harvest salmon. The hook-and-line method reflects the sustainable practice of taking enough fish for a family or community while leaving healthy, sustainable amounts of fish to spawn and migrate.

Image 2: A typical problem with certain kinds of modern nets is that they can be far too large and catch many non-commercial fish. This small Quileute set net, however, was made to target specific types and sizes of fish.
sources.question_text: How do these resources reflect the historical and contemporary importance of salmon fishing to the cultures, communities, and identities of coastal Native Nations?

sources.title: Ronnie Wilson
sources.body: “We’ve been out on boats all our lives; my dad was a fisherman when he was young; . . . we grew up here on the water, we grew up on boats. It seemed like we were fishing everywhere we went. We’d always throw a hook in the water somewhere, whether it’s in a lake or along the river, or wherever we went.”
sources.caption: Ronnie Wilson’s family has fished in the Pacific Ocean for generations. Salmon and other types of fishing define his identity as a Makah citizen and maintain the continuity of thousands of years of cultural traditions.
sources.excerpt: “We’ve been out on boats all our lives; my dad was a fisherman when he was young; . . . we grew up here on the water, we grew up on boats. It seemed like we were fishing everywhere we went. We’d always throw a hook in the water somewhere, whether it’s in a lake or along the river, or wherever we went.”
sources.question_text: What does Ronnie Wilson’s quote tell you about the significance of fishing to him and his family?
